The question is not whether Ethereum is trustless. 
It's whether the Ethereum Foundation will fight for a trustless ecosystem.

After six years building Boson as decentralized commerce infrastructure, I've learned: trustlessness is necessary but not sufficient.

A thread on why üßµ

‚Äî Justin Banon, Co-founder Boson Protocol
Six years ago, crypto had a common vision: build trustless systems that protect individuals from control, from dependence on intermediaries, and from the failure or corruption of human institutions.

That vision is fading. 
Today, amongst too many EF people, commercial pragmatism has primacy over trustless values.

The purpose we started with is being displaced. 

The same centralized players who dominated the old system are using our trustless rails to build the new one.
Throughout history, every tool meant to liberate has been co-opted: 
üîπ Governments meant to serve the people 
üîπFree markets meant to distribute opportunity 
üîπFree press meant to inform, not propagandize

All were captured, turned into instruments of control. 
Research on Werewolf/Mafia games reveals a structural truth: coordinated minorities consistently beat uncoordinated majorities.

Each centralized player operates as a tightly coordinated ecosystem with self-reinforcing advantages.
Network effects. Data moats. Capital efficiency. Distribution channels. Brand recognition.

These compound over time, creating overwhelming competitive advantage. 
Small trustless startups face insurmountable structural disadvantages.
The centralized players are already here: 

üîπ Coinbase offers "open source" protocols while maintaining centralized control 
üîπJP Morgan and Visa build on Ethereum with extractive business models 
üîπVirtuals ACP positions as decentralized but remains centrally controlled 
Ethereum has achieved trustlessness at the protocol level.

But without EF actively supporting the smaller trustless actors who embody Ethereum's values, those who merely use Ethereum will dominate.

What's the point if it becomes the foundation for centralized power? 
To fight for trustlessness means giving active preference to trustless projects to compensate for overwhelming structural advantages.

EF can pursue big partnerships but must also preferentially support decentralized, trustless infrastructure.
Without Ethereum Foundation tilting the playing field toward decentralized ecosystem players, the centralized minority wins simply by being more coordinated than the fragmented trustless majority.

Ethereum becomes the settlement layer for blockchain-enabled centralization.
The choice is stark: a decentralized economy where value is shared, or blockchain as the ultimate tool of centralized extraction.

Decentralization offers humanity a defense. 
For the first time, we can build systems where everyone shares in the value they create.
Ethereum has achieved something remarkable.

Now EF must choose: will it fight for what has been achieved, or watch it become the foundation for centralization?

This is about ensuring value created by commerce is shared by the many, not captured by the few.

‚Äî Justin Banon, Co-founder @BosonProtocol
